home.title: Our Story
home.desc:
Nestled among the rolling hills of Italy, there lies a place Taurasi where passion and tradition meet. This is the home of our winery and its secret treasure — a wine cellar filled with the finest wines from our vineyards. 

Our team dedicated itself to crafting the perfect bottles of wine, each a reflection of the land and our people. Our cellar is a testament to our love for the art of winemaking, a place where the finest grapes are carefully tended and transformed into the finest nectars. 

Immerse yourself in the rich heritage of Italian winemaking as you sample the rarest and most sought-after bottles

desc.title: Food Pairing
desc.value: It is accompanied with aperitifs, delicate seafood dishes and fresh cheeses

desc.title: Tasting note
desc.value: It has a Golden straw yellow color, intense and fruity aroma, with hints of citrus and quince

desc.title: Food Pairing
desc.value: Suitable for large roast dishes, cheese and salamis

desc.title: Tasting note
desc.value: It has a ruby red color with orange reflections, intense bouquet of black marasca and violet with hints of spices, black pepper and liquorice, an underground full-bodied, slightly tannic taste

desc.title: Food Pairing
desc.value: It accompanies fish or meat first courses, haute cuisine fish, white meats and semi-mature cheeses

desc.title: Tasting note
desc.value: It has a bright yellow color with light green shades, floral and fruity scent with citrus notes. In the mouth it is tasty, fresh and mineral with light hints of wood.

desc.title: Food Pairing
desc.value: It can be accompanied with seafood, risotto, delicate white meat

desc.title: Tasting note
desc.value: Soft straw yellow color, with hints of tropical fruit, hazelnuts, toasted walnuts and bitter almonds

desc.title: Food Pairing
desc.value: To be combined with meat-based dishes, cheese and roasts

desc.title: Tasting note
desc.value: It has a ruby red color, intense and persistent bouquet of red fruit with a spicy note of black pepper. Dry and harmonious flavor

desc.title: Food Pairing
desc.value: It is accompanied with aperitifs, fish-based dishes, white meats and fresh cheeses

desc.title: Tasting note
desc.value: It has a straw yellow color with greenish reflections, Fruity scent with notes of citrus and white flowers

desc.title: Food Pairing
desc.value: Excellent as an aperitif it goes with fish-based dishes and white meat

desc.title: Tasting note
desc.value: Straw-white color, with aromas that remind peach, quince and brush floral. With a pleasant bitter almond taste

desc.title: Food Pairing
desc.value: Accompanies dishes with a good aromatic depth: first courses with meat sauce, game, red roast meats, aged hard cheeses

desc.title: Tasting note
desc.value: It has a red color intense and brilliant ruby, tending towards garnet until it acquires orange reflections with ageing. The nose is powerful, rich in red fruits follows immediately by hints of more intense spices such as cloves and coffee

status.desc:
Italian wine label classifications are part of Italy’s appellation system for wine. These label classifications help consumers understand the quality of the wine they are buying and where it came from. 

Denominazione di Origine Controllata e Garantita (DOCG), is the highest quality level, was created in 1980 in response to criticisms that there were too many DOCs and their quality was variable. The first DOCG wines were Barolo and Barbaresco, both red wines made from the nebbiolo grape in Piedmont; and Brunello di Montalcino and Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, both red wines made from the sangiovese grape in Tuscany. There are now 74 DOCG wines in Italy, most of them concentrated in the regions of Piemonte, Tuscany, and the Veneto.

What Is the Difference Between DOC and DOCG Wines?
 The practical difference between DOC and DOCG is one of quality: DOC and DOCG wines are both wines with a designation of origin, but DOCG wines have an additional “garantita,” or guarantee, by the Italian government to be wines of especially high quality. Each DOCG-labeled wine must pass a wine quality tasting panel, while DOC wines must merely be grown and made in accordance with the rules of the appellation.

Italian wine label classifications are part of Italy’s appellation system for wine. These label classifications help consumers understand the quality of the wine they are buying and where it came from. 

Denominazione di Origine Controllata (DOC): The next highest quality level is Denominazione di Origine Controllata, or DOC, which means “designation of controlled origin.” There are 329 different DOCs in Italy, which cover many types of wine, from the sparkling wines of Prosecco, to the Vin Santo dessert wines of Tuscany, to a wide range of red and white wines across the country. Each DOC has its own rules about permitted grape varieties, maximum harvest yields, and aging requirements. 

What Is the Difference Between DOC and DOCG Wines?
 The practical difference between DOC and DOCG is one of quality: DOC and DOCG wines are both wines with a designation of origin, but DOCG wines have an additional “garantita,” or guarantee, by the Italian government to be wines of especially high quality. Each DOCG-labeled wine must pass a wine quality tasting panel, while DOC wines must merely be grown and made in accordance with the rules of the appellation.
